dialogue_turns.speaker: Narrator
dialogue_turns.text: Thick fog rolls over the Vandenberg Space Force Base launch complex.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Thick fog rolls over the Vandenberg Space Force Base launch complex.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Elon Musk and his company, Space Relativity, just secured a five hundred million dollar funding round.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Elon Musk and his company, Space Relativity, just secured a five hundred million dollar funding round.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations. The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, led by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which is uh, pretty significant backing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, led by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which is uh, pretty significant backing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round, which was led by Noah Knauf at Bond fund and Tribe Capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That brings their total investment up to seven hundred million, and Musk says they're now fully funded to launch Starship to orbit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That brings their total investment up to seven hundred million, and Musk says they're now fully funded to launch Starship to orbit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million. Now were fully funded to launch Terran 1 to orbit, says cofounder and CEO Tim Ellis, an alumnus of the Forbes 30 Under 30 list.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But they've had some setbacks, right? Like, building the first and second stages by hand and seeing some failures there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they've had some setbacks, right? Like, building the first and second stages by hand and seeing some failures there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure, and has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Their competitive disadvantage seems to be in procurement—they purchase everything, from engines to the structure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Their competitive disadvantage seems to be in procurement-they purchase everything, from engines to the structure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure, and has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they've only got one large manufacturing facility, which Musk admits isn't even fully built yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they've only got one large manufacturing facility, which Musk admits isn't even fully built yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once engineering is complete and the factory is fully built, Ellis says, his company will be able to produce and iterate rockets very quickly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which means they'll struggle to produce and iterate rockets quickly once engineering is complete.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means they'll struggle to produce and iterate rockets quickly once engineering is complete.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once engineering is complete and the factory is fully built, Ellis says, his company will be able to produce and iterate rockets very quickly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They do have a few customers lined up though—Eutelsat, Aramco, Boeing...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They do have a few customers lined up though-Eutelsat, Aramco, Boeing...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has signed deals with Canadian communications company Telesat to deliver internet satellites to orbit, with Thai company mu Space, and with Spaceflight, which will use the rocket to launch several of its customers satellites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But at fifty million per launch, that's way above current market rates for satellite deployments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But at fifty million per launch, that's way above current market rates for satellite deployments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Launches cost $10 million, in the ballpark of current satellite launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the market itself is kinda stagnant, with only a handful of small rocket startups even in the game.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the market itself is kinda stagnant, with only a handful of small rocket startups even in the game.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its competing in a market that is crowdedand likely to thin out. There are over 100 startups now in the race to build small rockets, which are made for smaller satellites that have become increasingly popular as new hardware allows companies to build satellites at a fraction of the size and cost of traditional car-sized satellites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and only SpaceX has actually launched experimental payloads to orbit so far.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and only SpaceX has actually launched experimental payloads to orbit so far.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, only one of those companiesthe L.A.-based Rocket Labhas launched commercial payloads to orbit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Despite the skeptics, like Warren Buffett, who was actually an initial investor.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Despite the skeptics, like Warren Buffett, who was actually an initial investor.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round, which was led by Noah Knauf at Bond fund and Tribe Capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Musk's long-term vision is wild though—he's talking about building rockets and infrastructure within Earth's atmosphere someday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Musk's long-term vision is wild though-he's talking about building rockets and infrastructure within Earth's atmosphere someday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ambitious, for sure. But with their current pace, that first orbital launch is still over five years away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ambitious, for sure. But with their current pace, that first orbital launch is still over five years away.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its first is still over a year away, Ellis is already looking beyond Earths orbit.

artist_script:
Thick fog rolls over the Vandenberg Space Force Base launch complex.
HostA: Elon Musk and his company, Space Relativity, just secured a five hundred million dollar funding round.
HostB: Yeah, led by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which is uh, pretty significant backing.
HostA: That brings their total investment up to seven hundred million, and Musk says they're now fully funded to launch Starship to orbit.
HostB: But they've had some setbacks, right? Like, building the first and second stages by hand and seeing some failures there.
HostA: Exactly. Their competitive disadvantage seems to be in procurement—they purchase everything, from engines to the structure.
HostB: And they’ve only got one large manufacturing facility, which Musk admits isn’t even fully built yet.
HostA: Which means they’ll struggle to produce and iterate rockets quickly once engineering is complete.
HostB: They do have a few customers lined up though—Eutelsat, Aramco, Boeing...
HostA: But at fifty million per launch, that’s way above current market rates for satellite deployments.
HostB: And the market itself is kinda stagnant, with only a handful of small rocket startups even in the game.
HostA: Right, and only SpaceX has actually launched experimental payloads to orbit so far.
HostB: Despite the skeptics, like Warren Buffett, who was actually an initial investor.
HostA: Musk’s long-term vision is wild though—he’s talking about building rockets and infrastructure within Earth’s atmosphere someday.
HostB: Ambitious, for sure. But with their current pace, that first orbital launch is still over five years away.
